
3.Report the number of NA's in each column.

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE}

library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(kableExtra)
library(knitr)
library(pander)
library(reshape2)
library(usmap)

beers = read.csv("beers.csv", header = TRUE,strip.white = TRUE)
colnames(beers) <- c("Beer_Name","Beer_ID","ABV","IBU","Brewery_ID","Style","Ounces")

breweries = read.csv("breweries.csv", header = TRUE,strip.white = TRUE)
colnames(breweries) <- c("Brewery_ID","Brewery_Name","City","State")

brewery_beer <- merge(breweries, beers, by=c("Brewery_ID"))

t_brewery_na <- data.frame(add_rownames(data.frame(sapply(brewery_beer, function(x) sum(is.na(x))), sapply(brewery_beer, function(x) sum(!is.na(x))), sapply(brewery_beer, function(x) sum(is.null(x))), sapply(brewery_beer, function(x) sum(n_distinct(x)))), "VALUE"))
colnames(t_brewery_na) <- c("Column","NA_totals","Not_NA_totals","Null_totals","Unique_totals")

pandoc.table(caption = "NA, Not NA, Null and Unique Total Counts", t_brewery_na, style = "grid")

```
